history.content: If your goal is to graduate in 3 years, then it's probably not gonna be much harder than your future semesters depending on the courses you chose to take. The 3 upper divs example you gave is probably just slightly lighter in terms of workload if not difficulty, and there may be ways to reorganize your (3)-yr plan to lighten your workload this semester, but you may as well go for it. If you planned to take mostly light upper divs and graduate early just to get a job as quickly as possible, maybe consider substituting 70 or 61c (depending on your interests, ML or SWE or etc.) for another EECS requirement to even out your next fall schedule (though keep in mind something like 61c+170 is arguably a tougher combo for some), otherwise this is a very common (albeit tough) combination of lower div. courses. Good luck with the semester!

children.subject: as an FYI, many students do take 4 techs.  I wouldn't dwell on it too much.  Just make sure to avoid certain combinations.

history.content: I am trying to graduate in 3 years instead of the usual 4, so I know that there will be semesters where I will have to take 3 techs. I understand that this will be an intense schedule, but is this lighter in workload and difficulty than let's say like 3 CS upperdiv classes such as CS188, CS170, and EECS126? Is there a way to fulfill the Physics requirement of EECS over the summer via an online class?
history.subject: [Schedule Advice] CS61C, CS70, and Physics 7A in one semester?
